summary: Orlando Bosch was a prominent Cuban exile leader involved in anti-Castro activities. The documents reveal his involvement in various events, including the bombing of a Cuban airliner, for which he was under investigation. He had connections to the CIA, though the extent of this relationship is not fully detailed in these documents. Bosch was under the protection of Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez at one point. He was imprisoned in Venezuela, and there were concerns about exile reprisals if he was released. Intelligence reports also mention his deteriorating health during a hunger strike. He used false Chilean identity documents. The documents span from the 1960s to the late 1970s, indicating a sustained period of activity. He is associated with other Cuban exiles and groups involved in anti-Castro activities, such as CORU.
significance: The Latin America Division (LAD) report, dated June 29, 1977, summarizes a task force investigation into possible Cuban complicity in the John F. Kennedy assassination, reviewing Agency operations against Cuba from 1960 to 1965 and finding no definitive proof of Cuban involvement.
